content.raw:
Thank you!

Before I accept this, I would like to find out why Python 3.6 complains about an unclosed file at `work_path` after running `test_prebuild_index`, despite there being a `close()` call after every use of `inst`. I wouldn't even think these were necessary after a `with` statement.

I'm not sure what's going on, especially since I don't see the warning when I comment out all methods but `test_prebuild_index`, but I do see it when I also uncomment another method (doesn't seem to matter which).
content.html:
Thank you!

Before I accept this, I would like to find out why Python 3.6 complains about an unclosed file at work_path after running test_prebuild_index, despite there being a close() call after every use of inst. I wouldn't even think these were necessary after a with statement.

I'm not sure what's going on, especially since I don't see the warning when I comment out all methods but test_prebuild_index, but I do see it when I also uncomment another method (doesn't seem to matter which).

content.raw: I think this was due to the reader instance created during `prebuild_byte_offset_file` not being explicitly closed and when a garbage collection happens might happen. By explicitly closing (using a with statement) the instance in that method after the index is built, the test seems to have stopped warning about a leaked file.
content.html: I think this was due to the reader instance created during prebuild_byte_offset_file not being explicitly closed and when a garbage collection happens might happen. By explicitly closing (using a with statement) the instance in that method after the index is built, the test seems to have stopped warning about a leaked file.

content.raw:
Ah, of course! Thank you!

This made me think again about the `classmethod` solution and I think that you are right and we need a public instance method for this.
I made a commit where I removed the underscore. I also commented out the `close()` calls in the test which shouldn't be needed after `with` statements. If that's ok with you, I'm ready to accept the PR. Or, if I forgot something, please let me know.
content.html:
Ah, of course! Thank you!

This made me think again about the classmethod solution and I think that you are right and we need a public instance method for this. I made a commit where I removed the underscore. I also commented out the close() calls in the test which shouldn't be needed after with statements. If that's ok with you, I'm ready to accept the PR. Or, if I forgot something, please let me know.

content.raw: No, all of that's good by me. Ready to merge when you are.
content.html: No, all of that's good by me. Ready to merge when you are.
